Class Guess

java.lang.Object
Guess
public class Guess extends Object
Guess class creates an array of JLabels to hold any type of guesses(player, computer and buffer). Methods below give an ability to compare and manipulate with guesses.

  • Constructor Details

    • Guess

      public Guess(int d)
      Parameters:
      d - (difficulty) is passed to the constructor determine how many labels a guess will hold.

  • Method Details

    • addElement

      public void addElement(JLabel element)
      Parameters:
      element - is a JLabel that is added to the array when a button is pressed.

    • compareElement

      public int compareElement(Guess playerGuess, Guess computerGuess)
      Parameters:
      playerGuess - is the guess that player made(an array of JLabels)
      computerGuess - is the guess that the computer made. Compares two guesses, deletes common elements from the guesses to avoid duplication.
      Returns:
      the number of white tiles to place (correct colour, but wrong position)

    • comparePosition

      public int comparePosition(Guess playerGuess, Guess computerGuess)
      Parameters:
      playerGuess -
      computerGuess - Compares the guesses in terms of both colour and position.
      Returns:
      the number of black tiles to press. (both requirements met).

    • copyPaste

      public void copyPaste(Guess guessOne, Guess guessTwo)
      Parameters:
      guessOne -
      guessTwo - copy pastes the elements of guessOne into guessTwo.

    • getElement

      public JLabel getElement(Guess computerGuess, int i)
      Parameters:
      computerGuess -
      i - the index an element of which is needed.
      Returns:
      the element of the given index

    • getArray

      public JLabel[] getArray()
      Returns:
      the JLabel array that makes up the guess(used in some calculations).

    • sizeOfGuess

      public int sizeOfGuess(Guess array)
      Parameters:
      array - the guess is passed to the method.
      Returns:
      the number of elements in the guess.
